text.title: According to all that he spoke:

pasuk.text: And where did he speak this? [As it is written], “And He shall give you rest from all your enemies [round about]” (Deuteronomy 12:10).

text.title: that He sustain the cause of His servant and the cause of His people Israel:

pasuk.text: to avenge their humiliation from their adversaries.

text.title: The same day the king consecrated the middle of the courtyard:

pasuk.text: These words are to be taken literally. This is Rabbi Yehudah’s view. [Solomon] hallowed the pavement of the court with the sanctity of the altar, in order to offer sacrifices on the pavement.
[i.e., the stone altar] that Solomon constructed in lieu of the copper altar [of Moses].

text.title: was too small to contain the burnt offerings and the meal offerings:

pasuk.text: for they brought very many. Rabbi Jose said to him, Is it not already written (Kings 1:3), “One thousand burnt offerings Solomon offered on that altar which Moses had made,” and when one computes the number of cubits and the number of burnt offerings, [he will find that] this one of stones was larger than Moses’, for on Moses’ altar the place of the ‘maarachah,’ the place usually used for the sacrifice, was but one cubit by one cubit, whereas on this one the place of its ‘maarachah’ was twenty- four cubits by twenty-four cubits. Hence Solomon’s was 576 times as large as that of Moses. If so, what is the meaning of “the king consecrated the middle of the court?” It means that he set the stone altar into it, fastened to the floor.
[According to Rabbi Jose] he is referring to that of Moses, like one who says to his friend, ‘So-and-so is a dwarf,’ meaning that he is disqualified to perform the sacrificial service.
which is in the north of Eretz Israel.
which is opposite it in the south, as is delineated in the section entitled אֵלֶה מַסְעֵי (Num. 34:5-8).
of the inauguration
of Succoth. It is found that they ate and drank on Yom Kippur.
to make known that He had forgiven him his sins, as we find in Moed Katan (9a): When Solomon wished [to bring] the Ark into the Holy of Holies, the gates clung to one another.
that He forgave them the sin of Yom Kippur, and a Bath-Kol [heavenly voice] emanated and declared: All of you are prepared for the life of the World to Come.

text.title: and My eyes and My heart shall be there at all times:

pasuk.text: Jonathan rendered: And My Shechinah shall dwell there if My will is done.

text.title: And My eyes and My heart shall be there:

pasuk.text: if My heart and My will are there.

text.title: and this house which I have made sacrosanct for My Name:

pasuk.text: There is a condition between Me and You, “If you heed not…” What is stated there? “I shall make desolate your sanctuaries” (Lev. 26:31).

As the Targum renders: וּלְשׁוּעִי and for a topic of conversation. They will tell [about the] evils [that] have befallen them and will scoff at them. Just as וַיְסַפֵּר“and he told” (Gen. 37:9) the Targum renders וְאִשְׁתָּעֵי. The expression שְׁנִינָה too is an expression of speech, as in וְשִׁנַּנְתָּם לְבָנֶי “And you shall repeat them to your children” (Deut. 5:7).

text.title: And this house will be exalted:

pasuk.text: as long as you have not sinned. And from the time you will sin, every passerby will be astounded and will hiss. And so it is written in Chron II 7:21: “And this house that was exalted by everyone who passed by it…” And this is its interpretation: And this house that was exalted and revered even by the gentiles, as is stated above: “And also to the gentile who is not of Your people…” (Chron. II 6:32), now in its destruction, everyone who passes by it, even the gentiles, will be astounded and will hiss, and will say that the Jews’ sins were the cause.
יִשֹּׁם in Heb. will wonder, like “… and your enemies will wonder (ושממו) about it.” (Lev. 25:32. Also, “Concerning his day the later ones will wonder (נשמו) ” (Job 18:20).
siffler in French. Such is the habit of anyone who suddenly sees desolation, to hiss.
i.e., seven years for the Temple, and thirteen years for his own palace, as mentioned above 6:38, 7:1.
An expression of bearing, i.e., he bore his burden in this matter.
A land of chains; i.e., a muddy land into which the foot sinks and is entrapped.

text.title: And this is the matter of the tax levy:

pasuk.text: delineated at the end of this topic (below v. 20- 21).“All the remaining people… of them did Solomon raise a levy of forced labor.” This tax levy was to build therewith all these [structures].
Heb. מלוא, a place that was in Jerusalem, in the city of David, that was called Millo, since it was enclosed by a low wall and was filled (מלא) with dirt.
a dowry.

text.title: And Tadmor in the desert in the land:

pasuk.text: near civilization.
cities of storehouses.

text.title: These were the commanders of the officers:

pasuk.text: That is to say, those who were appointed subordinate to the officers who were in overall command.

Three hundred of them were proselytes appointed over the 70,000 who bore burdens and the 80,000 hewers in the mountains, and the 3,300 who bore rule over the people, as stated above: “Besides Solomon’s chief officers… three thousand and three hundred” (5:30). And in II Chron. (2:1) it is stated: “six hundred.” These three hundred that are missing here (5:30), he counted there, for they were appointed over all of them. The two hundred and fifty remaining were Israelites appointed over the other laborers. In II Chron. (8:10) he counted them separately: “And these were Solomon’s chief officers two hundred fifty who bore rule over the people who did the work.”
who was originally in the city of David, as it is stated in the beginning of this book (3:1): “and he brought her to the city of David.”

text.title: came up from the city of David:

pasuk.text: … In Chronicles (II 8:11) Scripture explains: “… for he said, A woman shall not live with me in the city of David (the exact wording is: ”… in the house of David, king of Israel.“) for they [the entire city and all the houses] are holy, for the Ark of the Lord was brought in to them.”
i.e., Solomon.

(See above v. 15) to build within it houses for her manservants and maidservants. Concerning this Jeroboam admonished him, saying: Your father left it open for the pilgrims, and you enclosed it to make a labor force for Pharaoh’s daughter. This is [the inference of] “But” mentioned here. But in this did Solomon sin. So have I heard. I say, however, But Pharaoh’s daughter… i.e., the above mentioned cities were necessary to build for store- cities, for chariots, for riders, and for greatness. But, the Millo he did not build for any greatness, for his father had left it for the pilgrims to pitch their tents therein, but since Pharaoh’s daughter had gone up to her house, and the Millo was adjacent to that house, then he built up the Millo.
i.e., the altar of the Temple.

text.title: and burning upon it, upon the altar that was before the Lord:

pasuk.text: And that incense altar that was before the Lord for the burning of incense.
[The usual word is אֳנִיָה] a ship.

text.title: and his ascent by which he would go up to the Temple of the Lord:

pasuk.text: A passageway that he had prepared from his house to the Temple, by which he would go up to the house of the Lord.
corail in French.

text.title: a path to the House of the Lord:

pasuk.text: [lit. a support.] In II Chron. 9:11 it is written, מְסִלּוֹת, paths to the House of the Lord. I, therefore, say that this מִסְעָד, support, is an expression of a pavement.
for the Levites.

text.title: And King Solomon gave the queen of Sheba:

pasuk.text: This giving refers only to the teaching of wisdom.
He cohabited with her and Nebuchadnezzar was born to her. He later destroyed the Temple that had stood 410 years in the territory of the twelve tribes.From the Arizal.

text.title: aside from what he gave her:

pasuk.text: Gifts and delicacies that are found here and are not in her place.

Hiram gave him 120 talents (v. 14). The Queen of Sheba, 120 (v. 10), the ships of Tarshish brought from Ophir 420, totaling 660. I do not know from where the other six came. In Chronicles (II 8:18) it stated that the ships brought from Ophir 450 talents, however it does not include the 120 talents of Hiram. We can resolve the contradictions [by saying] that the extra 30 were from the 120 of Hiram. because Hiram’s servants were in Ophir with his [Solomon’s] servants.

text.title: Aside from [that which came through] merchants:

pasuk.text: the merchants who traversed the land on business would bring to him.
Dealers of spice would carry them from city to city.
Heb. וכל מלכי הערב. Jonathan Translates: מלכי סומכותא, and all the dependent kings, an expression of guarantee. Kings who granted support and were dependent on him; garantie in French.
Heb. צנה, a body shield that encircles the person from three sides. This is the meaning of the verse in Psalms (5:13), “You shall encompass him with will like a shield (כַּצִנָּה).”
Six manehs, for a piece of gold (זָהָב) is a dinar [and one hundred dinars total one maneh].
It is soft and easy to flatten out.
Heb. זהב מופז, which sparkles like diamonds.
steps by which to ascend onto it, and the top of the throne was circular, i.e., the place of the king’s seat.
The steps were to the front and to the width. To the back was the seat, a round place, higher than the throne.
on which to support his arms, like two gold rails from corner to corner, extending on the right and on the left.
of gold. The entire plan of the throne is described in the Aggadah of the Book of Esther.

text.title: none was of silver, [since] it was reckoned with as nothing:

pasuk.text: Lit. there was no silver; it was not reckoned… i.e., there was no silver in any of them because it was not reckoned.
Ships of Africa.
Elephant tusks, monkeys and peacocks.

It is stated [that Solomon had] one thousand four hundred [chariots]. I say that one thousand four hundred were in the chariot cities and [the remaining] three hundred were with the king in Jerusalem. And this is the explanation [of the verse] in Chron.: “And he stationed them (i.e., the 1,400) in the chariot cities and with the king”; [i.e., with the king] there were other chariots in Jerusalem. While here this is the explanation: And he led them (i.e., the 1,400) in the chariot cities, and with the king; i.e., with the king were some of them in Jerusalem.
Our Rabbis explained that one refers to the time before Solomon wedded Pharaoh’s daughter, and one refers to the time after Solomon wedded Pharaoh’s daughter.

[was] from Egypt. The assemblage of horse merchants was in Egypt. Solomon’s merchants bid and bought the rights from the king of Egypt, that no person could export horses from there except through them. Therefore, there is a ‘Zakef Gadol’ on the word ‘Mikvei,’ to denote that the word ‘Mikvei’ [stands by itself, and] is not connected with the following words.

text.title: and a horse for one hundred fifty:

pasuk.text: We deduce that a chariot consisted of four horses. And so for these prices to all the kings of the Hittites and to the kings of Aram.
Through Solomon’s merchants did they export them from Egypt.

She too was one of the foreign women, but since she was beloved by him more than all of them, she was counted separately. Similarly, (II Sam. 2: 30) “… and there were missing of David’s servants nineteen men and Asahel.”

text.title: Then did Solomon build a high place:

pasuk.text: Our Rabbis said, Since he did not protest against his wives, it is referred to on his name.

text.title: on the mountain that is before Jerusalem:

pasuk.text: The Mount of Olives.

text.title: For as this has been with you:

pasuk.text: i.e., you knew that you were transgressing My precept.

text.title: And it was when David was in Edom:

pasuk.text: Then Hadad fled before David and Joab.

for they buried the slain of Edom. This is what is referred to in the Book of Samuel (II 8:13): “And David made for himself a name when he returned from smiting the Edomites,” for all were praising him as a kind man who buried his slain. And so Scripture says concerning the wars of Gog and Magog: (Ez 39:13) “And they will bury all the people of the land, and it will be for them for a name.” [However,] Jonathan [translated]: לְחַלָצָא יַתקְטִילַיָא, to strip the slain, to take their clothing.
He said to his attendants, So much bread shall you give him every day.
Heb. הגבירה, lit. the mistress.

text.title: That David slept with his fathers:

pasuk.text: concerning David who died a natural death, an expression of sleeping is mentioned, whereas concerning Joab who was killed, [an expression of dying is mentioned (Eccles. R. 7:1; Mid. Shmuel)]. Another explanation is that concerning David who was survived by a meritorious son who took his place, an expression of sleeping is mentioned, whereas concerning Joab who was not survived by a meritorious son who took his place, no expression of [sleeping is mentioned, but an expression of dying].

text.title: And God raised up against him an adversary,:

pasuk.text: against Solomon. Now this is what Nathan the prophet said to David (Sam. II 7:14) so that when he goes astray, I will chasten him with the rod of men.

text.title: with the evil that was caused by Hadad:

pasuk.text: Together with the evil that was perpetrated by Hadad, was also this evil of Rezon.

text.title: raised his hand against the king.:

pasuk.text: He rebuked him in public.
concerning which he rebuked him.

and with this building he closed up the breach behind the Millo. He said to him, Your father made breaches in the wall for the pilgrims to enter, and you fenced it in, to create a labor force for Pharaoh’s daughter, to station there her manservants and maidservants.
prior to this.

text.title: that he was a diligent worker.:

pasuk.text: Lit. that he was doing work. Quick in his work and diligent.

text.title: Over all the burdens of the house of Joseph:

pasuk.text: Over all the taxpayers of the house of Joseph [Targum Jonathan], Manasseh and Ephraim, since he was from the tribe of Ephraim.
Heb. ניר, a kingdom. ניר is an expression of a yoke.

For in the days of the Messiah the kingdom will be restored to him. In Seder Olam (ch. 15) I found: “I shall afflict David’s descendants because of this. Corresponding to the thirty-six years that Solomon was married to Pharaoh’s daughter, for he married her during the fourth year of his reign. Corresponding to this, the decree was promulgated on the kingdom of the house of David to be divided. The kingdom should have been restored, however, in Asa’s time, in the sixteenth year of his reign, but he sinned by sending a bribe to the king of Aram (below 15:18), and did not depend on the Most Holy, Blessed be He. This is the meaning of that which is stated in Chronicles (II 16:1). In the thirty-sixth year of Asa’s reign Baasha built the high place.” This is impossible, since Asa buried Baasha in the twenty-seventh year of his reign (i.e., Baasha died in the twenty-seventh year of Asa’s reignI Kings 15:33). Rather, the sixteenth year of his reign, Scripture calls “the thirty-sixth,” for they are the end of thirty-six years from the division of the kingdom, and Scripture tells us that in that year Asa sinned. Thus we explain: “But not for all times,” [but thirty-six years].

text.title: My little finger is thicker than my father’s loins:

pasuk.text: Heb. קטני, my little finger.
aiguillon in French, a goad or sting [called so] because they sting like scorpions.
The Temple that you built, will be for you alone.
He was Adoniram [mentioned above in 5:28].
Who were situated on the border, for the boundaries of Judah and Benjamin were adjacent.

Sitting in the Temple court is not permitted except for the kings of the house of David only. Therefore, he [Rehoboam] will be seated and I will be standing. Moreover, in the year following the Sabbatical Year, at the time of the Assembly, he will read the portion relating to the king, for he is the king of his province, whereas I will be like the rest of the people, and will, therefore, find myself degraded.
at the end of the boundary of the land.
He expounded to them that this was the month of ingathering, and was, therefore, the proper time for the festival to be [celebrated].

text.title: that he had fabricated from his heart:

pasuk.text: Heb. אשר בדא מלבו, an expression of falsehood (controver in O.F., to invent).

text.title: And behold a man of God:

pasuk.text: This was Iddo.
[Both the one] that is in Beth-El and [the one] that is in Dan.
[This refers to the bones] of Jeroboam, but the prophet dealt him respect.

text.title: And he gave a sign on that day:

pasuk.text: The prophet gave a sign on the day on which he prophesied. This is your sign: the altar will split by itself and the ashes will be spilled to the ground.

The Holy One, Blessed be He, avenged the honor of a righteous man more than [He avenged] His own honor. [When] he was standing and offering sacrifices to pagan deities, his hand did not become stiff, yet because of the disdain for the righteous man his hand became stiff.
but not my God. He was still in a state of rebellion.
standing and burning sacrifices to idols.
and eat.
a false prophet.
He was not from there but from Samaria. So it is stated in the section dealing with Josiah (II Kings 23:18). And they saved his bones with the bones of the prophet who had come from Samaria.
the false prophet.
Who brought back the man of God. From here they deduced that offering refreshment is a great thing, for it causes the Shechinah to rest on the prophets of the Baal.
The old prophet called the man of God.

text.title: for the prophet whom he had brought back:

pasuk.text: [i.e., for the prophet] whom this one had brought there, for the man of God to ride upon.
[i.e.,] in the graveyard belonging to the false prophet in the city.

text.title: For the thing… will come to be:

pasuk.text: [i.e., the prophecy mentioned above in v. 2] and human bones they will burn upon you. Perhaps his bones will rescue my bones.

that he saw this wonder and heard the words of the prophet, he, nevertheless, did not return. And our Rabbis expounded: After the Holy One Blessed be He grasped him by his garment and said to him, Repent and I and you and the son of Jesse will stroll in Paradise.
Heb. ונקדים. A type of parched grain, dried in an oven. They make flour from it to make it into a dish known in the language of the Gemara as ‘shethitha.’
as though she were not this one.
from the Holy One Blessed be He with a harsh message.
Jonathan renders: One who knows knowledge; one who places [wisdom or counsel] into the walls of his heart.

text.title: those who are restrained and those who are free:

pasuk.text: Heb. עצור ועזוב. עצור is one who has someone restraining his hand, similar to “This one shall rule over (יעצור) My people” (Sam. 9:17). ועזוב means one who has no one restraining his hand.
As the one who [consumes food to make] it eventually into dung, so will I expunge after him until he is completely consumed.
For he absented his watch, for his father had stationed him as a sentry so that no man would go up on the pilgrimage festivals. Instead, he absented his watch and he himself went up.

text.title: who will cut off the house of Jeroboam this day, and also those who will be born from now on.:

pasuk.text: [Those] who are already born to him this day, and those who are destined to be born to him from now on. So did Jonathan render.

text.title: the city that the Lord had chosen:

pasuk.text: Yet, even so…

text.title: And Judah did what displeased the Lord:

pasuk.text: and they did not pay attention to this.
Heb. ויקנאו [usually used in the sense of jealousy or zeal but here is] an expression of angering.
[like the other] tribes.

We find in Midrash Shir Hashirim: This was Pharaoh Neco. He was called Shishak because all his life he longed for (שוקק) the ivory throne that belonged to Solomon his son-in-law. Now, he went up and took it.
the throne that was dearer to him than everything.
before him in honor. Afterwards, they would return them to the chamber where the runners were always stationed.

text.title: And in the eighteenth year of King Jeroboam:

pasuk.text: One year after Rehoboam’s death. Now in the twentieth year of Jeroboam, Asa reigned. The third year of Nadab [Abijam] is counted for King Asa as a year, and for him it is also counted.
Jonathan renders: And he abolished the prostitutes.
Heb. מגבירה, [lit. from queen,] from being queen.

text.title: for she had made a frightful image:

pasuk.text: Our Rabbis stated: [מפלצת is a combination of] מפליא ליצנותא, it carried lasciviousness to an extreme. She made for it a phallic symbol, and she would copulate with it every day.

text.title: The high places he did not remove:

pasuk.text: The private high places upon which they had become accustomed to sacrifice to Heaven since Shiloh had been destroyed until the Temple was built, when the high places were permissible, were not removed now. Even though they were forbidden when the Temple was built and the people were punished by premature death because of it.
[lit. no one was exempt.] Even a bridegroom concerning whom it is stated (Deut. 24:5) “He shall be free for his house one year.”
the second and the third year of Asa.

text.title: During the third year of Asa, king of Judah, Baasha the son of Ahijah, reigned:

pasuk.text: The third year of Asa is counted for Nadab and Baasha.

text.title: Nevertheless, in the hand of Jehu the son of Hanani, the prophet, was the word of the Lord concerning Baasha:

pasuk.text: As though to say: Behold Elah reigned. Nevertheless, the word of the Lord was already in the hand of Jehu that his kingdom would not last.

text.title: and because he had slain him:

pasuk.text: Since he too, committed the same sins, [lit. went in his sins,] it is found that he should not have slain him. He was, therefore, punished for his murder. So do we find in Hosea (1:4), “And I will visit the blood of Jezreel upon the house of Jehu.” Since they did not turn away from Ahab’s ways, they were punished for their murder.
He and another were captains over the chariots.
nor his kinfolk nor his friends.
When Asa took Omri’s daughter in marriage for Jehoshaphat his son, they killed Tibni, when they saw Omri’s importance. In Seder Olam (Ch. 17).

text.title: In the thirty-first year of Asa… Omri ruled:

pasuk.text: a complete, [uncontested,] reign. Five years was [the duration] of his conflict with Tibni, from the twenty-seventh year of Asa until the thirty-first.
was the total, five years in conflict and seven with a complete reign. It is impossible to say [that he reigned] twelve years uncontested, for Ahab his son reigned in the thirty-eighth year of Asa.

text.title: in Tirzah he ruled six years:

pasuk.text: while he had not yet built Samaria.
in addition to Jeroboam’s calves.
a tree that was worshipped.

Heb. ביתהאלי, similar to “Jesse the Bethlehemite (ביתהלחמי)” (I Sam. 16:1), and it does not say הביתלחמי. And so, “Joshua the Bethshemeshite (ביתהשמשי)” in the Book of Sam. (I 6:14), and not הביתשמשי, and so, “In Ofrah of the Abiezerites (אבי העזרי)” (Jud. 6:25), and it does not say, האבי עזרי. Some interpret ביתהאלי [from the word אלה, a curse,] since he accepted upon himself Joshua’s curses, “Cursed be the man… that rises up and builds…” (Jos. 6:26). Our Rabbis stated, Hiel was of the tribe of Benjamin, and Jericho belonged to Jehoshaphat [king of Judea]. Why does Scripture relate him to Ahab [king of Israel]? For a curse is related to a cursed one.

text.title: with Abiram his firstborn he laid its foundation:

pasuk.text: When he laid its foundation, his firstborn son died, and he buried him and continued to bury all his sons until the last one died when he erected the portals. Now, these were Joshua’s curses, “With [the loss of] his firstborn shall he lay its foundation, and with [the loss of] his youngest son shall he set up its gates” (Jos. 6:26).
from a land named Toshav.

Why was this placed here? For Elijah and Ahab went to console Hiel in his mourning. Said Ahab to Elijah, Is it possible that the disciple’s curse was fulfilled while Moses our teacher’s curse was not fulfilled, as it is said: (Deut. 11:15) “And you will turn and worship other gods, and bow down to them, the Lord’s wrath will be kindled against you, and He will shut up the heaven.” Now, all Israel are worshipping idols, and the rains are not being withheld. Immediately, Elijah… said…
from Ahab and Jezebel.
in order that that he know the necessity of rain and trouble himself to go into exile, for it was displeasing to the Holy One, Blessed be He, that Israel should live in hunger.
the name of a city.
in My household that a widow shall feed you there.

text.title: Please take to me a little water:

pasuk.text: He did not recognize the widow concerning whom the Holy One, Blessed be He, had told him. He learned from Eliezer, the servant of Abraham, (Gen. 24:15), and said, The one who gives me water is the widow.
Heb. מעוג [like עוגה, a cake].
Jonathan rendered: the palm of a handful.
bouteille in French, [a bottle,] as it is stated regarding Saul, “the jug (צפחת) of water that was at his head” (I Sam. 26:16).
From then on, we will die of hunger.

text.title: but first make for me a small cake:

pasuk.text: There is a Midrash Agadah in Gen. Rabbah (why he wanted his cake first) on the verse: “And Leah said, ” Good fortune has come" (Gen. 30: 11).
became ill in order that he should need the key of Resurrection of the dead, as it is stated at the end of the Agadah of chapter Chelek (San. 113a).

text.title: to cause my sin to be remembered:

pasuk.text: Before you came, the Heavenly Tribunal would weigh my deeds and the deeds of the people of my city, and I was worthy of a miracle. Since you have come, here, I am not counted as anything since my righteousness is not noticeable And similarly, concerning Lot Scripture states: “And I am not able to flee to the mountain” (Gen. 19:19) to Abraham, for my merit will not be remembered in comparison to his.
Heb. ויתמודד, from an expression of מדה, a measure, i.e., he prostrated himself upon him.

text.title: And it was when Jezebel cut off:

pasuk.text: [Scripture] comes to tell [us] how Obadiah feared the Lord.
[i.e., fifty men in one cave] and fifty men in another cave.

text.title: and we will not lose all our beasts:

pasuk.text: all our beasts will not be cut off from us.
as he goes on to explain (v. 12) “And a wind from the Lord will carry you to a place I know not where.”

text.title: that they did not find you:

pasuk.text: [i.e., he made them swear] that the nation was unable to find you.
two thoughts, for you do not know to decide who is God.
is God, go after him.

text.title: And the people did not answer him a word:

pasuk.text: because they did not know to distinguish.
For he slipped away from them lest he be offered to the idol. He escaped under the skirt of Elijah’s cloak. He said to him, Go! Through both of you the Omnipresent will be sanctified.

text.title: and they hopped on the altar that they had made:

pasuk.text: Jonathan renders: And they raved. They were dancing according to their custom, on their altars.
Heb. ויפסחו, like ויפסעו, and they stepped.
for you say he is one to be feared.

text.title: Perhaps he is talking or he is pursuing:

pasuk.text: Perhaps he is having a conference with his advisors now, or he is overtaking and pursuing his enemies in war.

text.title: or he is on a journey:

pasuk.text: to the water closet.
an expression of tearing [the flesh] with an instrument. Such was their custom.
and they raved.

text.title: and he repaired the torn down altar of the Lord:

pasuk.text: He built an altar and reminded Israel that the altar of the Lord should enter their thoughts and should be spoken of with fluency, for it was torn down and destroyed and its name and its mention had ceased from the mouth of all the ten tribes. Thus I heard its simple interpretation. And its Midrashic interpretation I have heard, that Saul built an altar on Mt. Carmel. That is what [Scripture means when] it states: (I Sam. 15:12) “Saul has come to Carmel, and behold, he is setting up a place,” and there (Gen. 33:20) it says: “And he set up an altar there.” [By a gezerah shavah, analogous expression, we deduce that Saul too, set up an altar]. And the kings of Israel tore down all the altars and high places in their land that were made in the name of Heaven, and Elijah built this altar of Saul that was torn down.

text.title: to whom the word of the Lord came, saying, “Israel shall be your name.”:

pasuk.text: Why is this stated here? Because on the day that the Shechinah was revealed to Jacob in Bethel and called him Israel, on that day He said to him, “A nation and a congregation of nations will be from you” (Gen. 35:11). Your children are destined to congregate like other nations and build an altar to burn sacrifices on it during the time when the high places are proscribed. Nevertheless, I will consent to it (Gen. Rabbah 82:6).
fosse in French.

text.title: as great as would contain two se’ah:

pasuk.text: Its width was as great as to hold two se’ah, one hundred cubits by fifty cubits like the court of the mishkan.
to make the miracle greater.

Elisha poured on his hands, and his fingers became like springs, and the trench became full. This is the meaning of what is stated (II Kings 3:11): “Here is Elisha the son of Shaphat who poured water on Elijah’s hands, and a miracle took place with the water through him.” He is fit that a miracle should take place with water through him.

text.title: and at Your word I have done:

pasuk.text: that I sacrificed on a high place at the time of the prohibition of high places.

text.title: Answer me, O Lord, Answer me:

pasuk.text: Answer me with fire, answer me with rain. So did Jonathan render this. Our Rabbis, however, said: Answer me with fire, answer me that they do not say that these deeds were accomplished by sorcery.

text.title: shall know that You are the Lord:

pasuk.text: and I am Your servant, and when You send me to bring them tidings [of the forthcoming redemption], they will believe me if You answer me today.

text.title: and You have turned their hearts backwards:

pasuk.text: You have given them a place to turn away from following You, although You were able to direct their hearts toward You. And according to Midrash Agadah, if You do not answer me, I will deny and say, You turned their hearts. And so did Moses say (Num. 16:29), “If these people die the death of all men, I, too, will deny and I will say that the Lord did not send me to speak [the words of] the Torah and the commandments,” and so said Micaiah (below 22:28), “If you return safely, God did not speak through me.”
and the Baal is not God.

text.title: and he crouched on the ground:

pasuk.text: And he crouched on the ground to pray for rain.
If you see a cloud ascending from the sea.
Hitch up your chariots and descend quickly from Mt. Carmel, to return to your house, lest the rain oppress you on the way.
While the messenger went, and while he hitched up the chariot, the heavens grew dark.

text.title: And a spirit of strength from the Lord:

pasuk.text: A spirit of strength from before the Lord. He became invested with strength to run before the chariot on foot, so that Ahab would not go alone, for he paid regards to royalty.
Heb. וישנס, like ויאזר, yet there is no similar word [in the Bible], and even this one came only to teach us an expression of quickness, i.e., he was as quick as a strong man.
as you have done to the prophets of the Baal.
or genievre in French, a juniper tree.

text.title: and requested that his soul die:

pasuk.text: He said, EnoughMy long life is enough. Until when will I be confused like this?
Heb. רצפים, charcoal, and similarly, (Isaiah 6: 6) “and in his hand was a coal (רצפה).”
That is the cleft of the rock where Moses stood (Ex. 33:22).

text.title: They have torn down Your altars:

pasuk.text: The private high places that were built in the Name of Heaven, for the altar of the Temple was in Jerusalem.
A camp of angels of the wind.
A camp of angels of earthquake.
A camp of angels of fire.

Jonathan renders: כריך אפוהי, and so Scripture says: “wrapped in a garment (לוטה בשמלה)” (I Sam. 21:10).

text.title: you shall anoint to be prophet in your stead:

pasuk.text: I do not want your prophecy since you plead for the prosecution of My children.
We do not find that Elisha killed anyone except the forty-two children through the bears in Jericho (II Kings 2:24).
from following me.

text.title: for what have I done to you:

pasuk.text: that you should follow me.

text.title: he cooked the meat for them:

pasuk.text: Heb. בִּשְׁלָם הַבָּשָׂר. The mem of bishelam [is usually indicative of the direct object, to be rendered,] he cooked them. [In this case, however, since the object is] habassar, [the meat, we render:] he cooked for them the meat, so Dunash and Menahem (Machbereth Menahem, p. 48) explain, and so did Jonathan render this in two words. [‘bashilu lehon,’ he cooked for them.] I say, however, that it is unnecessary to divide it into two words [i.e., to add the preposition to]. Now what is the meaning of בִּשְׁלָם הַבָּשָׂר ? He cooked the two oxen, their flesh; [i.e., he cooked them, viz. their flesh.] For the yoke is no fewer than two. [Therefore the plural suffix is used.]
Out of great joy, he made a feast.

text.title: As I have sent to you, saying, Your silver… you shall give to me.:

pasuk.text: As I have sent to you… you will give to me I know that you will give to me, but another thing I am decreeing upon you.

[lit. anything desirable to your eyes.] Now were not the first things desirable things? What, then, is the meaning of “anything you prize” ? This means a prize within a prize [i.e., a possession prized more than any other prized possessions.] This is the sefer Torah, concerning which it is written, “… that are prized more than gold and much fine gold” (Ps. 19:11). Said Ahab to himself, He demands a great thing. This is not mine alone; this belongs to the elders of Israel. He, therefore, summoned all the elders of the land. Even though they worshipped idols, they respected the Torah.

text.title: if the earth will suffice for the footsteps:

pasuk.text: [Jonathan renders:] To take with the footsteps of all the people who are with me, i.e., earth that adheres to the sole of the feet for the footsteps. לשעלים is an expression of treading with the sole of the foot, similarly, (Num. 22:24) במשעול הכרמים, “in a path between the vineyards.” And similarly (Is. 40:12): מי מדד בשעלו מים, “Who measured the water with his step,” for he trod in the Sea of Reeds, as it is stated: (Hab. 3:15) “You trod in the sea with Your horses.”
Heb. אם ישפק, if there is enough.

text.title: Say, One who girds himself with the sword shall not boast as one who unties the sword:

pasuk.text: Say to him, One who girds himself and goes down to war shall not boast like a man who has been victorious and is coming up from it. One who girds his sword to go down to war, who does not know whether he will be victorious or not, should not boast.

text.title: as one who ungirds the girdle of his sword,:

pasuk.text: who has already come up from the war victorious. Similarly, your master should not boast concerning a future thing.
the implements of siege against the city.
That was Micaiah the son of Imlah.

text.title: With the youths of the governors of the providence.:

pasuk.text: They are the hostages for all the princes of the other nations would give their children into his custody lest they rebel against him.
Who will array [the battle] to command it.
You go forth first and so you shall kill him. [According to Shem Ephraim, the reading is:] And you shall not wait, and you shall array [the battle].
I say that they are the ones concerning whom Scripture stated (above 19:18), “all the knees that did not kneel to the Baal, seven thousand.”
that they had made for themselves because of the sun.

text.title: at the return of the year:

pasuk.text: at the time of the end of the year.

text.title: and place officers in their place:

pasuk.text: Since they are not of a highborn family, they will endeavor to exert themselves in order to find favor.

text.title: if we will not overpower them:

pasuk.text: i.e., and you will see if we will not overpower them.
provided with supplies for the war; they armed themselves with weapons and all necessities of war.
they were sustained.

Heb. עזים חשפי, flocks of goats, although there is no comparison [in the Bible]. Menahem, however, classifies this with the expression of revelation, like (Gen. 30:37) מַחשּׁוף הלבן“laying bare the white”; (Is. 47:2) חשפי שבל “uncover your locks.” The expression of revelation fits with flocks of goats, like (Song of Songs 4:1) “… who bared Mt. Gilead.” When they come down from the mountain, it is bared [or revealed].

text.title: and said to the king of Israel. And he said:

pasuk.text: Said R. Johanan: Every place wherein it is stated, And he said… and he said, must be expounded. The first saying [refers to what] he said to him, “… I will deliver all the great multitude into your hand…” The second saying [alludes to an admonition that], “if Ben-Hadad falls into your hands, show him no clemency.” Therefore, when he took pity on him, he said to him (v.42) “Since you released the man I had designated for destruction…”

text.title: took it for an omen, and they hastened and caught it from him:

pasuk.text: Heb. יְנַחֲשׁוּ is an expression of divining. They said: Since words of peace fell from his mouth, even inadvertently, it is a good sign, and they hastened to confirm the matter.
i.e., Ben-Hadad said to Ahab, The cities that my father took from your father Omri, I will return to you.

text.title: and you shall make streets for yourself in Damascus:

pasuk.text: and rule therein, although it is the capital of my kingdom.

text.title: as my father had made in Samaria:

pasuk.text: your city against your will. He was saying all this out of fear. Said Ahab to him, And I will, with this treaty, release you.

This sign was bad for Ahab, for the prophet said to him by the word of the Lord to kill Ben-Hadad, and he did not kill him. Also, this one to whom the prophet said by the word of the Lord, “Strike me,” and he did not strike him, just as He punished him, he would punish Ahab.

text.title: By the word of the Lord:

pasuk.text: The Holy One, blessed be He, said that you shall strike me.
[He struck him] a wounding blow.

text.title: and he disguised himself with his headband:

pasuk.text: He changed his headband so that they would not recognize him. Any change of clothes is an expression of disguise.
Heb. באפר. Jonathan rendered this במעפרה, [that is] a headband.

text.title: and behold, a man turned aside:

pasuk.text: from the road to me.

text.title: and he brought to me a man:

pasuk.text: a prisoner of war.
If he escapes, an expression similar to (Num. 31: 49) “and no man was missing from us (ולא נפקדו) ”; an expression of a lack.
He ran away.
Either your life or a talent of silver.

text.title: the man whom I designated for destruction:

pasuk.text: the man of My war, an expression of חרם, strife. Now, the expression of strife fits with war, and similarly, (Is. 34:5) “… on Edom it will descend and on the nation with whom I war (חרמי).” [Thus we render, “the man with whom I war.” [According to the] Midrash Aggadah: Many traps and nets have I spread for you until he fell into your hand.
Heb. סר וזעף. [Jonathan renders:] נסים ודוי, his spirit turned away from him. [These are expressions of sadness.] His spirit turned away from him.

text.title: And it was after these happenings:

pasuk.text: [lit. after these things,] still another incident to bring his death close.
[lit. the worth of this, i.e.,] the worth of this vineyard.
wicked and ignorant elders, elders of shame.
On a fast day it was their custom to search for the sins in their hands.
Heb. ברך, [lit. blessed, a euphemism for קללה,] curse. The Targum renders: Naboth blasphemed against God and cursed the king.

Some of our Sages say that the property of those executed by the king belong to the king. And some of them say that he [Ahab] was the son of his [Naboth’s] father’s brother. He killed him and his children [as well], and was therefore fit to inherit his [property].
You sold yourself to anger your Creator. Heb. התמכרך, you sold yourself [reflexive form] like (Deut. 28:68) והתמכרתם, “and you will sell yourselves there to your enemies.”
Heb. חל, the Aramaic translation of valley.

text.title: But there was none like Ahab:

pasuk.text: The Scripture testifies concerning him that there was none among the kings like him, for Jeroboam and all those after him worshipped the calves out of fear that if the people would go up to Jerusalem, the kingdom would return to the house of David, but this one [Ahab] added the Baal and the Asherah to anger God.
was sold to idolatry. I saw in Yerushalmi that Hiel was his counselor, and every day he [Hiel] would estimate his [Ahab’s] value and he [Ahab] would give it to the pagan deities.

text.title: and put sackcloth on his flesh, and he fasted:

pasuk.text: he walked barefoot.

text.title: I will not bring the disaster:

pasuk.text: i.e., the disaster of his house I will not bring in his days, but the decree that the dogs will lick his blood is impossible to come in the days of his son, but upon him.
since he had released Ben-Hadad.
We are lazy [siamo pigri in Italian].

text.title: Is there no other prophet of the Lord here?:

pasuk.text: I have a tradition that no two prophets prophesy with one expression, and these are all saying the same expression.
For he said to me, Since you released the man whom I designated for destruction…
He did not say it to him in the name of the Lord.

text.title: and may the Lord deliver it:

pasuk.text: If only the Lord deliver it into the king’s hand.

You alone will perish in the war, as it is stated below (v. 31), “Do not battle with great or small, except with the king of Israel only.” Even though it was stated, (above 20: 42) “and your people instead of his people,” the drop of blood that came out of the righteous man, Micaiah, whose friend struck him, striking and wounding him, was an atonement for all Israel. So it is explained in the Aggadah.

text.title: On His right and on His left:

pasuk.text: Now is there left in Heaven? It is not stated, (Ps. 118:16) “The right hand of the Lord is exalted; the right hand of the Lord does valiantly” ; (Ex. 15:6) “Your right hand, O Lord, is mighty with power; Your right hand, O Lord, dashes the foe” ? But rather, the passage means that these would stand on the right and these would stand on the left. Those who stand on the right present the case for the defense and those who stand on the left present the case for the prosecution.

text.title: And a certain spirit came forth:

pasuk.text: The spirit of Naboth.

text.title: Which did the spirit of the Lord pass:

pasuk.text: Which way did it pass? This is an abbreviated verse. In II Chron. 18:23, it is written: “which way (דרך) did… pass.”

text.title: And the king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, I will disguise myself and go into battle:

pasuk.text: [lit. disguise and go into battle. He told Jehoshaphat of his plans] to disguise himself and go [into battle]. I will disguise myself I will change my regal garb, lest they recognize me, for if they recognize me, they will turn to me to attack me.

text.title: and you wear your regal garb:

pasuk.text: that you are wearing, for you are not the king of Israel, but the king of Judah, and with you they have no conflict.
to the Holy One, Blessed be He.
This was Naaman.
not knowing that he was the king of Israel.

text.title: between the scales and the coat of mail:

pasuk.text: Some coats of mail are made of layers of scales, in the manner it is stated (I Sam. 17:5) “and a coat of mail,” and the scales fall on the holes of the coat and close them, and they are called דבקים.
He exerted himself to remain standing so that the Israelites would not become aware of his wound and flee, for flight is the beginning of defeat.

text.title: and the dogs licked his blood:

pasuk.text: I say that Naboth was killed there, for the prophet said, “In the place that the dogs have licked the blood of Naboth…” (21:19).

text.title: and they washed the weapons there of the blood:

pasuk.text: Jonathan rendered it in this manner. Our Rabbis said, [however, rendering ‘zonoth’ as harlots,] “Ahab was a cold person [who disliked sexual relations” (San. 39b)]. Therefore, Jezebel made for him the image of two harlots in his chariot to stimulate him. [When the chariot was washed, these two images were washed in the pool of Samaria.]
Heb. ביתהשן, lit. the palace of the tooth, i.e.,] elephant tooth.

text.title: Jehoshaphat made peace with the king of Israel:

pasuk.text: Since there was war between Assa his father and Baasha the king of Israel, it was necessary to say this.
who fornicated in public.

text.title: There was no king in Edom:

pasuk.text: Since the time of David, the governor was the king This was written here because in the days of Jehoram his son who sinned, in his days Edom rebelled and crowned a king for themselves, but in the time of Jehoshaphat they were still subordinate to him.

Since he joined Ahaziah in this undertaking, therefore, they were broken. And so did the prophet say to him in II Chron. (20:37), “Because you have joined a wicked man (sic), the Lord has caused a breach in your undertaking.”

text.title: in the seventeenth year of Jehoshaphat:

pasuk.text: Some wonder about this verse, since it is stated concerning Ahab that he reigned twenty-two, and concerning Jehoshaphat it is stated that he became king in the fourth year of Ahab. It is found that Ahab’s rule ended in the nineteenth year of Jehoshaphat. Yet here [Scripture states that Ahaziah became king in the seventeenth year of Jeohshaphat. However, I searched and found that concerning most kings of Israel [Scripture] is not exact in the number of their years, and if one became king at the end of a year, he counts it at the beginning, but he does not count it elsewhere. Therefore, I say that “in the fourth year of Ahab” (v. 41) that is mentioned in reference to Jehoshaphat’s becoming king, does not count with it Ahab’s first year. And so you find in the majority of cases. Also, the year in which Jehoshaphat became king is not included in these seventeen years.
